title: RS21342
content: The diversity visa lottery encourages legal immigration from countries other than major sending countries to the US. It was added to the Immigration and Nationality Act in 1990 to promote new and varied migration. The current lottery began in FY1995 after temporary lotteries. The Diversity Visa Lottery, established in 1990, aims to promote new and varied migration to the US. It provides 55,000 visas annually to natives of countries with lower immigrant admissions in the previous five years. The allocation of visas is based on regional populations. The Diversity Visa Lottery, established in 1990, allocates visas based on regional populations. Each country is limited to 7% of the visa limit, with recipients becoming legal permanent residents of the United States. Northern Ireland is treated as a separate foreign state. The lottery has not been directly amended since its inception. The Diversity Visa Lottery, established in 1990, allocates visas based on regional populations. Each country is limited to 7% of the visa limit, with recipients becoming legal permanent residents of the United States. Northern Ireland is treated as a separate foreign state. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act of 1997 temporarily reduces the annual visa ceiling by up to 5,000 visas. Beginning in FY1999, the diversity ceiling became 50,000 to offset immigrant visa numbers for certain unsuccessful asylum seekers. The diversity visa lottery, established in 1990, allocates visas based on regional populations. Each country is limited to 7% of the visa limit, with recipients becoming legal permanent residents of the United States. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act of 1997 temporarily reduces the annual visa ceiling by up to 5,000 visas. In FY2002, 42,829 persons were admitted or adjusted as LPRs with diversity visas, representing 4% of all LPRs. In FY2002, 42,829 individuals were admitted as legal permanent residents with diversity visas, accounting for 4% of all LPRs. The top five countries sending diversity immigrants were Albania, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Poland, and Ukraine. These countries, along with Bangladesh, Bulgaria, Morocco, Romania, and Russia, have consistently been among the top diversity visa senders. Ireland, Poland, and the former Soviet Union used to win the most visas in the mid-1990s but their participation has decreased in recent years. Albania has been the top sending country throughout this period. In FY2002, 42,829 individuals were admitted as legal permanent residents with diversity visas, accounting for 4% of all LPRs. The top sending countries for diversity immigrants were Albania, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Poland, and Ukraine. Ireland, Poland, and the former Soviet Union used to win the most visas in the mid-1990s but their participation has decreased in recent years. Albania ranks as the top sending country, followed by Nigeria, with Russia and Ukraine possibly understated due to reporting issues. In FY2002, diversity visa recipients were born in the Soviet Union. The top sending countries for diversity immigrants were Albania, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Poland, and Ukraine. European immigrants comprised 39.4% of diversity visa recipients, while African immigrants received 38.1%. Caribbean, Latin American, and Asian immigrants dominated family-based and employment-based visas. In FY2002, diversity visa recipients were born in various countries, with European immigrants comprising 39.4% and African immigrants receiving 38.1% of the visas. To be eligible for a diversity visa, an alien must have a high school education or two years of relevant experience. The Diversity Visa program requires applicants to have a high school education or equivalent, or two years of relevant work experience. Winners undergo reviews by Department of State consular officers and DHS inspectors to ensure they meet visa eligibility criteria. State consular officers and DHS inspectors review applicants to ensure visa eligibility under INA grounds for inadmissibility. Exclusion criteria include health, criminal history, security concerns, public charge, unauthorized work, illegal entry, citizenship ineligibility, and prior removal. FY2005 lottery announced on August 19, 2003, with a 60-day application period from November 1 to December 30, 2003. The FY2005 diversity lottery was announced on August 19, 2003, with a 60-day application period from November 1 to December 30, 2003. Applications had to be submitted electronically, and entrants from countries with high immigration rates were usually ineligible. Ineligible countries for FY2005 included Canada and China. For the FY2005 diversity lottery, paper forms were not accepted, and applicants from countries with high immigration rates were usually ineligible. Ineligible countries included Canada, China, Colombia, Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Haiti, India, Jamaica, Mexico, Pakistan, the Philippines, Russia, South Korea, the United Kingdom, and Vietnam. Petitioners had to follow State Department instructions precisely to avoid disqualification. When applying for a diversity visa, petitioners must follow State Department instructions precisely to avoid disqualification. In the FY2003 lottery, over 2 million applications out of 8.7 million were disqualified for not complying with the instructions. Aliens can be disqualified for submitting more than one application, but spouses and unmarried children under 21 can submit separate entries. Any derivative beneficiary must be listed on the initial petition. Husbands and wives can submit separate entries for the diversity visa lottery, even though spouses and unmarried children under 21 qualify as derivative beneficiaries. Derivative beneficiaries must be listed on the initial petition, and if the lottery winner dies before obtaining LPR status, the visa is revoked. Winners are selected randomly by computer, and those not selected are not notified by the State Department. Winners of the FY2005 diversity lottery will be notified by the State Department between May and July 2004. Visas will be issued between October 1, 2004, and September 30, 2005. Winning the lottery does not guarantee a visa as more applications are received than visas available. Winners of the FY2005 diversity lottery must act quickly to file necessary documentation by September 30, 2005. In-person interviews are expected to start in October 2004. Some question the continuation of the lottery due to long wait times for family visas. Some question the continuation of the diversity visa lottery, preferring the 55,000 visas be used to reduce backlog in other visa categories. Supporters argue the diversity visa brings new immigrants to a system dominated by family-based immigrants. There are calls to amend the INA to restrict nationals from certain countries. Some argue that the diversity visa lottery brings new immigrants to a system dominated by family-based immigrants. Critics suggest amending the INA to prevent nationals from terrorism-sponsoring countries from participating in the lottery due to difficulties in background checks and terrorism concerns. Supporters believe the policy should be uniformly applied to all visa categories. Supporters of the diversity visa lottery argue that concerns about terrorism should prompt changes in the program. There is debate over who should bear the costs of operating the lottery, with some suggesting a fee should be charged to enter the lottery. The State Department acknowledges criticisms of the program's vulnerability to fraud and misuse but asserts they are addressing these concerns.
